info.title: NPR Station Finder Service
info.description: Allows clients to look up NPR member station information

externalDocs.description: Learn more at the NPR One Developer Center

get.summary: List stations close to you or filter by search criteria
get.description:
This endpoint has two main use cases:

- If no query parameters passed in, it returns a list of stations that are geographically closest to the calling client (based on GeoIP information)
- If one or more query parameters are passed in, it performs a search of NPR stations that match those search criteria (not taking into account the client's physical location)

Clients wanting to implement a 'Change Station' UI should use this endpoint to power their search. In most cases, you'll want to build a search interface that uses one of the 3 provided schemas: `lat` and `lon` (using e.g. the HTML5 Geolocation API), `city` and `state`, _or_ the generic `q` query which can accept a station name, call letters, network name, or zip code. Technically speaking, `q` can also take in either a city name or a state name, but using the `city` and `state` parameters together will yield more accurate geographic search results than `q={cityName}`.

The `lat` and `lon` query parameters should always be passed in together (otherwise the API will return a 400 error), and if included in the query, they will take precedence over any other search criteria; that is, `lat` and `lon` will do a purely geographic search and not take into account `q`, `city` or `state`.

Similarly, `city` and/or `state` will take precedence over (and ignore) `q`.

If clients want to be able to offer multiple types of searches (e.g. 'Search for a station name, city or zipcode') using a *single* search input form, `q` should be used. But again, be aware that using `city` and `state` together will yield more accurate search results than `q={cityName}`.

parameters.name: Authorization
parameters.description: Your access token from the Authorization Service. Should start with `Bearer`, followed by a space, followed by the token.

parameters.name: q
parameters.description: Search terms to search on; can be a station name, network name, call letters, or zipcode

parameters.name: city
parameters.description: A city to look for stations from; intended to be paired with `state`

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: A state to look for stations from (using the 2-letter abbreviation); intended to be paired with `city`

parameters.name: lat
parameters.description: A latitude value from a geographic coordinate system; only works if paired with `lon`

parameters.name: lon
parameters.description: A longitude value from a geographic coordinate system; only works if paired with `lat`

200.description: A list of one or more stations matching the search query

get.summary: Retrieve metadata for the station with the given numeric ID
get.description:
This endpoint retrieves information about a given station, based on its numeric ID, which is consistent across all of NPR's APIs.

A typical use case for this data is for clients who want to create a dropdown menu, modal/pop-up or dedicated page displaying more information about the station the client is localized to, including, for example, links to the station's homepage and donation (pledge) page.

parameters.description: Your access token from the Authorization Service. Should start with `Bearer`, followed by a space, followed by the token.

parameters.name: stationId

content-type.description: The MIME type of the response of this link

daysSinceLastListen.description: The number of days since a user last listened to a story from this aggregation. Absent if user never listened to the aggregation.

following.description: Whether or not the user is following the aggregation. When changing affiliation status, the client is expected to toggle this value and then send the entire object back.

href.description: A link to more details about the program from the NPR Story API

id.description: A unique identifier for the aggregation (program)

notif_following.description: The topic in Firebase Cloud Messaging to which the device should subscribe if it supports notifications and the user wants notifications about the podcasts they follow.

notif_rated.description: The topic in Firebase Cloud Messaging to which the device should subscribe if it supports notifications and the user wants notifications about the podcasts they have highly rated.

rating.description: The user's average rating for this affiliation on a scale of 0-1. Absent if user never listened to the aggregation.

Affiliation.description: A program (aggregation) that a given user has shown an affiliation with

band.description: The subsection of the radio spectrum -- 'AM' or 'FM' -- where this station can be heard

call.description: The three-to-four-letter identifying code for this station. Please use this with caution; most stations prefer to be identified by their `name` in client applications instead of `call`.

frequency.description: Where on the radio dial the station can be heard. If the `band` is AM, the frequency will be between 540 and 1600. If the `band` is FM, the frequency will be between 87.8 and 108.0.

marketCity.description: The city that the station is most closely associated with. This may or may not be the city the station is licensed in and it may or may not be the city that the station or the station's antenna is located in.

marketState.description: The state that the station is most closely associated with. This may or may not be the state the station is licensed in and it may or may not be the state that the station or the station's antenna is located in.

name.description: The display name for the station. In most cases, this will be the same as `call` letters combined with band. When returning networks, it will return the network name (e.g. Minnesota Public Radio).

tagline.description: A short text-logo for the station

StationBrandData.description: An associative array of brand-related metadata for this station

StationBrandLink.description: A link to a web page, logo, or audio file related to the branding of the station

rel.description: A short string identifier describing the way the way the link relates to the document

guid.description: The system's internal unique identifier for a station, not typically used by other APIs or consumers

orgId.description: The system's unique ID for this station, used across NPR One Microservices and NPR's other APIs

StationDonationLink.description: A link to a pledge page for the station

typeId.description: An identifier for the type of link; '4' denotes a generic pledge page, while '27' is an NPR One-specific pledge page

format.description: The format of the programming on this station

localization.description: Whether or not this station should be shown in search for news context, any context or no context

musicOnly.description: Whether or not this station only plays music.  Deprecated.

nprOne.description: Whether or not this station is considered an NPR One station

status.description: The status of the station within NPR's system, not typically used by consumers

StationEligibilityData.description: An associative array of eligibility-related metadata for this station

StationLink.description: A link related to the station

guid.description: The system's internal unique identifier for a link, not typically used by consumers

title.description: The link text, provided by the station, for the URL

typeName.description: The semantic name corresponding to the `typeId`

donation.description: One or more links to audio files related to this station

podcasts.description: One or more links to podcasts related to this station

streams.description: One or more links to audio streams related to the station

StationListDocument.description: A collection of stations close to you or filtered by search criteria
